Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: its a review of the basic foundations of calculus
I learned the basics of calculus I, including limits, derivatives, differential equations, optimization, and basic integrals.
Single Variable Calc! Pretty foundational math class.
This course covered the basic concepts and fundamentals of Calculus.
Quite broad understanding of limits, graphs, functions, and their rekations to derivatives and anti derivatives, along with the ability to apply this information in real world problems.

I thought this class gave a very process-based approach to calculus. Formulas were very rarely given off the bat- they were typically discovered through an in depth process that we did during class. In that sense I felt that my critical thinking was expanded, and I was able to make mathematical connections to areas of study outside of the Math department. I'm now able to think about rates of change in a variety of ways, and almost in a simpler manner.

I learned how to find limits, take derivatives, and integrate. Each topic encompassed a variety of methods and applications. Problem sets were challenging and allowed me to develop my critical thinking skills.
I learned a lot of information for calculus this semester. I enjoyed the class and feel prepared to take Math 115 next semester.
I learned about the basic functions of calculus beginning with limits and ending with applications of derivatives.
I learned about calculus.
I developed problem solving skills and the ability to use the tools i acquired to apply them to harder problems.

I had previously learned nearly all of the information taught in this course, but I did learn how to manage my time in this class. I rather quickly came to the realization that PSETs are not meant for the night before!
Could be more about calculus in the beginning and less about pre-calculus
It is a lot of work and can sometimes be confusing, but overall does a great job of teaching you the basics of calculus.

I think it's well taught; having us buy a special type of textbook with a special online package was ridiculous though, I really don't have $150 to spend on this. That being said, it was useful to have the online pre-class quizzes to keep me on track. So I do get the appeal, but having to spend over $100 is just too much...
I think the grading in this course was very reasonable. The instructors gave us sufficient practice and resources to achieve the grade that we wanted.
There is alot of work that becomes a bother for someone with a busy schedule
The support the peer tutor schedule gives is huge. A negative is the scarcity of assessments, as a bad test can be huge in terms of an overall grade.

Overall I felt like this class did the job as far as giving students a basic introduction into Calculus. It checked all the boxes (derivatives, integrals, approximations, etc) but it really let me down in that there was almost no student engagement. This type of class (which I essentially took in high school) can be more effective when students learn out loud and discover things out together. I understand that things need to move class in order for calculus 1 to be taught in a semester, but with it being taught as a lecture, I lost focus and got bored very easily.
Very fast paced, it the students in the course all start at the same level (with little to no exposure to calculus)
The course could be improved by providing more in class practice of skills as opposed to just lecture, but overall information was presented very clearly.

The strengths of this class are the problem sets that we have to complete each week in order to gain a stronger understanding of the material. Although we used webassign as well, sometimes I felt that using it was a weakness because entering the answers was confusing rather than helpful.

The course could have been more engaging during class time; the class period often felt long when there was so little discussion or interaction with the professor beyond just taking notes. However the content was intriguing and the notes always helpful, so I certainly got a lot out of my time spent in the class.

The strength of the course is that there is a very developed curriculum. The weakness of this course is that the curriculum makes it difficult when specific sections get a little behind, given that the homework is the same in all sections.
The in class examples could have been more applicable to the problem sets and test problems but overrall my knowledge of calculus is greatly improved.

This course is pretty good at offering help to students struggling with Psets or WebAssign. The office hours are plentiful and helpful, but only if you know when and where they are. The Psets are graded very unclearly. My experience was that graders could just take off points for whatever they want. The tests were reasonable for the most part.
There is way too much homework its impossible to keep up with it
Good for math majors. Not super interesting.
Yes if you don't want a very difficult math class, especially if you've already taken calculus
If you have to take calculus, then yes, but if you don't need it for your major, then no.
Well. It's a great intro class so yes?
Yes; I think the course was very well taught. It is a good way to learn the fundamentals of calculus.
not unless it was required as a pre req or part of a major program

This class is essentially a pre-req that students will have to take in order to move on to more interesting topics, so in that sense I guess I have to recommend it. Was it particularly interesting and engaging? -Nope. But am I a math/science person? -Nope.
I would readily recommend Math 112 to another student.
I would definitely recommend this course!
This course is a great way to get an introduction to calculus; it is in depth and interesting in all of the ways it applies to real life.
I would recommend this course to students who feel they didn't develop a great understanding of calculus in high school.

I would only recommend this course to another student if it was required for their major. Do not take this course just for kicks and giggles. It will also be annoyingly difficult if you've taken AP AB Calculus before, but definitely take 112 and not 115 if you only took AB in high school.
if you have to take it take it but its not very engaging as a course
